Conjunctivitis is an eye condition caused by infection or allergies. It usually gets better in a couple of weeks without treatment.

sections.title: If you're not sure it's conjunctivitis
paragraphs: Find out about other conditions that can cause red eyes

sections.title: How to treat conjunctivitis yourself
paragraphs: There are things you can do to help ease the symptoms of conjunctivitis.
Do not wear contact lenses until your eyes are better.

sections.title: A pharmacist can help with conjunctivitis
paragraphs: Speak to a pharmacist about conjunctivitis. They can give you advice and suggest eyedrops orantihistaminesto help with your symptoms.
If you need treatment for a child under 2 years old, you'll need a prescription from a GP.

sections.title: Stop infectious conjunctivitis from spreading
paragraphs: There are things you can do to stop conjunctivitis spreading to other people.

sections.title: Do
paragraphs: wash your hands regularly with warm soapy water
wash your pillow cases and face cloths in hot water and detergent
cover your mouth and nose when sneezing and put used tissues in the bin

sections.title: Don’t
paragraphs: do not share towels and pillows
do not rub your eyes

sections.title: Staying away from work or school
paragraphs: You do not need to stay away from work or school unless you or your child are feeling very unwell.

paragraphs: These can be signs of a more serious eye problem.
You can call 111 orget help from 111 online. Call 111 if you need help for a child under 5.

sections.title: Treatment for conjunctivitis
paragraphs: Treatment will depend on the cause of your conjunctivitis.
If it's a bacterial infection, you might be prescribedantibiotics. But these will not work if it's caused by a virus (viral conjunctivitis) or an allergy.
Some sexually transmitted infections (STIs) can cause conjunctivitis. This type takes longer to get better.
